titleStmt.title: Doha, Qatar National Library (مكتبة قطرالوطنية), HC.MS.03193

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

availability.p: Image credits: Qatar National Library, Heritage Library.

msContents.summary:
Shelfmark: QNL HC.MS.03193; Single folio (fragmentary); Writing surface: Parchment; Qurʾānic text: recto 43:71-89: caesura from 44:1-15; verso 44:15-42;
Script: kūfī, ductus: Close to B.Ia; Dimensions: Current dimensions of fragmentary leaf: 207 x 283 mm; Estimated date of production: circa 700-750. Notes on the dimensions: Estimated dimensions of original complete leaf: 340-360 mm x 290-310 mm; Estimated dimensions of original complete text area: 270 x 240 mm The folio is damaged at the top and bottom edges. There are 19 surviving lines on each side, fragmentary at upper and lower edges, with visible elements of at least one more line at the upper and lower edges. As a result 15 verses of Qur’ānic text have been lost from this folio. Based on the dimensions of the surviving leaf and the text that remains, it can be estimated that around 13-15 lines of text have been lost. It is clear that there is at least one line above the current uppermost line, since there are traces of the sublinear letters visible. Equally, a fragmentary line is visible at the lower edge. It is not possible to know whether the 15 missing lines were mostly lost from the top or bottom of the folio, but either way we can estimate the original dimensions of the text area to have been approximately 270 x 240 mm and the overall dimensions of the original leaf (including margins) to have been approximately 340-360 mm x 290-310 m. The shape of the folio was therefore taller than its width (i.e. a vertical rectangle), and was probably very close to the proportions of BNF Arabe 331 (see Déroche 1983, p. 67, no. 15, pl. IX; https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b84152099/f1.planchecontact.r=graphie%20B%20I ) or perhaps to those of BNF Arabe 327 (https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b84152062/f1.planchecontact.r=graphie%20B%20I#) both of which are written in script style B I (although vertical letters in BNF Arabe 331 are taller and the script and lines more spacious, and the script of BNF Arabe 327 is more sharply angular). In the earliest phase of Qur’ān manuscript production, the vertical format preceded the square and rectangular format and was associated mostly with Qur’āns in ḥiǧāzī script. The script of the present leaf is B.Ia, which is closely related to ḥiǧāzī and indeed should possibly be considered a form of ḥiǧāzī (Déroche 1992, p. 35). The vertical format of the present leaf as well as certain letter forms (see below) suggest it is an early example of a post-ḥiǧāzī transitional B script. Verse markers: Single verse divisions are marked with a triangular cluster of three short dots/dashes, each being the shape of the nib point of the stylus and written in the same brown ink as the text (type 1.1.4, see Déroche 1992, p. 21). Tenth verse divisions are marked with a small circle surrounded by a ring of dots in the same brown ink as the text. Sura headings: The sura heading of Sura 44 is written in red ink at the bottom of the recto. The surah heading is not written in same hand as the main Qur’ānic text on this folio, but the letter forms certainly appear to be early. Indeed, certain letters of the red script are closer to ḥiǧāzī forms than to kūfī types A or B, such as the ḏāl of hāḏihī and the final nūn of ḫamsūna. Recent provenance: Sotheby’s, London, 22 October 1993, lot 28 (dimensions were given as 205 x 290 mm). Sister folios: No other folios from this Qur’ān are currently known.

support.p: The recto is the flesh side; the verso is the hair side. Quire structure: not known.

summary.p: Diacritics: most of the letters that require diacritics in standard scripts have the requisite points here, except for the yā’, which is never pointed. The individual dots are applied in the same brown ink as the script and are formed by placing the nib of the stylus once on the parchment at a diagonal angle (i.e. we can see the approximate shape of the nib of the stylus from the shape of the letter-points). On letters that require more than one point (e.g. tā’, ṯā’ etc), the dots are placed one above the other at a slight diagonal, but this line of dots can vary from near vertical to near horizontal. For example, the letter ṯā’ in line 9 of the verso has an almost vertical line of dots above the letter, whereas in line 17 of the verso it extends at a shallow angle approaching the horizontal. For the letter šīn, a single dot is placed above each denticle so that the three points are effectively arranged in a horizontal row above the letter. For the letters fā’ and qāf, in most instances of the letter fā’ there is a dot placed above the circular letter body (as in standard scripts), but there are a few instances where the dots are absent. In contrast, the letter qāf is never pointed on this folio. The vowels signs are indicated with red dots and green dots. The script of this Qur’ān is perhaps a transitional script between late ḥiǧāzī scripts and kūfī scripts. There is considerable line discipline on the verso, but on the recto this is less consistent and the lines sag slightly in the central area and then slant upwards towards the end of the line. Most of the letter forms are closest to style B.Ia, but there are some individual letter forms that are closer to A.I, B.Ib and B.II. For example, the final nūn is generally closest to B.Ib, but certain examples are closer to A.I or B.II, whereas none are close to B.Ia. There is also variation in the form of different instances of the same letter. For example, the ʾalifs generally accord with script type B.Ia, but the exact form varies considerably, with a number of examples having a shorter ascender and others having a more rounded curve, while some slope slightly forward rather than backwards, the latter which Déroche states is a diagnostic feature of B.Ia (Déroche 1992, p. 38). The lām-ʾalif combination is closest to B.Ia but there is some inconsistency in the exact form, with some instances having ascenders that diverge slightly. Some examples of ṭāʾ and ẓāʾ are close to B.Ia while others are closer to B.II; the letters ‘ayn and ġayn are closest to B.Ia; the final qāf is closest to B.Ia, but the exact forms varies slightly; the final mīm is closest to B.Ia. Many of the ascenders slant to the right, a characteristic of ḥiǧāzī scripts (see Déroche 1992, p. 35). The ascenders of ʾalif and lām when used in conjunction, as in the word Allah, are not parallel but slant inwards towards each other, i.e the ʾalif slopes slightly to the left and the lam slopes slightly to the right. This is an interesting variation on the B script types and may be a further indication that the present script was produced at a formative stage of B script evolution. These multiple inconsistencies and variations in letter forms on a single folio, along with the (original) vertical format and form of the verse markers, may be diagnostic of a transitional status between ḥiǧāzī the codified regularity of kūfī scripts, and therefore points to a date in the first half of the eighth century (for a discussion of B scripts and their relation to each other and to ḥiǧāzī scripts, see Déroche 1992, pp. 35-6, 38-9). It is also interesting to note that a correction to the text has been added using a form of the letter ʾalif that is archaic: on line 14 of the verso the spelling of the word balā’un has an ʾalif added at the end in a different hand and a different ink from the main script, and this added ʾalif slants to the right and has a very short lower tail, a form that is close to some ḥiǧāzī scripts such as those found on the Codex Amrensis (see e.g. Déroche 1992, no. 2, p. 31; Déroche 2014, fig. 18). This suggests that the correction was inserted at a time when some ḥiǧāzī scripts were still in use in certain contexts, since the scribe who made the correction did not attempt to replicate the form of ʾalif used in the main script of this folio nor use a letter-form associated with slightly later script types such as D. This suggests that the original B.Ia script of this folio must also have been coeval with an ongoing or belated use of ḥiǧāzī scripts. This would also accord with the somewhat archaic form of the red script used for the sura heading.
